chapter.title: Command Reference
chapter.para: This chapter describes all SQL commands provided by Mychem. These commands are classified in five sections:

listitem.para: Conversion Commands - this section details functions that convert chemical files.
Helper Commands - this section details functions that return informations about the Mychem environment.
Modification Commands - this section details functions that modify chemical structures.
Molmatch Commands - this section details functions that compare chemical structures.
Property Commands - this section details functions that compute molecular properties.

sect1.title: The molecule Type
sect1.para: Many functions are using or returning a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format. Since version 0.6.0 of Mychem, the DEFAULT_TYPE format is MDL Molfile (V2000). In earlier versions, the DEFAULT_TYPE format was InChI.

The speed of several functions has been measured when using InChI and MDL Molfile formats. It has been shown that using MDL Molfile is a bit faster than InChI. Using the MDL Molfile format is also interesting, as it permits to store 2D or 3D coordinates. Moreover, the MDL Molfile format is commonly used by many softwares.

sect1.title: Conversion Commands
sect1.para: Conversion commmands permit to convert chemical data from a format to another format. Mychem uses the Open Babel library for the conversion, but does not implement all the 80 chemical file formats supported by Open Babel. Mychem supports only few of them. They are detailed in .
To avoid having to many functions, a set of two functions is available for each format: FORMAT_TO_MOLECULE and MOLECULE_TO_FORMAT. If you need other formats, please request it on the feature tracker.

note.para: If a function of this section fails, it returns an empty string.

listitem.para: CML_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in CML format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_CML() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in CML format.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT MOLECULE_TO_CML(molecule_col) FROM tbl_name -> WHERE name='2-Aminoacetic acid'; -> <molecule id="id2-Aminoacetic acid"> <name>2-Aminoacetic acid</name> <atomArray> <atom id="a1" elementType="H" x3="-0.106800" y3="-1.052100" z3="1.150900"/> <atom id="a2" elementType="C" x3="0.087700" y3="-0.079800" z3="0.647700"/> <atom id="a3" elementType="H" x3="-0.287000" y3="0.708200" z3="1.333100"/> <atom id="a4" elementType="N" x3="1.518500" y3="0.191900" z3="0.395100"/> <atom id="a5" elementType="H" x3="2.016800" y3="0.126600" z3="1.256800"/> <atom id="a6" elementType="H" x3="1.889000" y3="-0.469300" z3="-0.254400"/> <atom id="a7" elementType="C" x3="-0.677500" y3="-0.076700" z3="-0.657800"/> <atom id="a8" elementType="O" x3="-0.445500" y3="-0.696800" z3="-1.679800"/> <atom id="a9" elementType="O" x3="-1.785100" y3="0.699100" z3="-0.670500"/> <atom id="a10" elementType="H" x3="-2.210100" y3="0.648900" z3="-1.521200"/> </atomArray> <bondArray> <bond atomRefs2="a1 a2" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a2 a3" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a2 a4" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a2 a7" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a4 a5" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a4 a6" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a7 a8" order="2"/> <bond atomRefs2="a7 a9" order="1"/> <bond atomRefs2="a9 a10" order="1"/> </bondArray> </molecule>

listitem.para: FINGERPRINT() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a fingerprint. The fingerprint type is specified by the second argument (FP2, FP3 or FP4). The SQL type of the converted molecule is a binary string for all kinds of fingerprint.

note.para: Tanimoto scoring can be improved by using a concatenation of different fingerprint types. The concatenation of fingerprints can be performed with the following query:
note.screen: mysql> SELECT CONCAT(FINGERPRINT(molecule_col,"FP2"), -> FINGERPRINT(molecule_col,"FP3")) FROM tbl_name -> WHERE id=9; -> binary fingerprint (type FP2 + type FP3)

listitem.para: FINGERPRINT2() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a FP2 fingerprint. The SQL type of FP2 fingerprints is a binary string.
FINGERPRINT3() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a FP3 fingerprint. The SQL type of FP3 fingerprints is a binary string.
FINGERPRINT4() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a FP4 fingerprint. The SQL type of FP4 fingerprints is a binary string.
INCHI_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in InChI format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_INCHI converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in InChI format.

note.para: The function permit to know which version of the InChI library is used.

listitem.para: MOL2_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in Sybyl Mol2 format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_MOL2() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in Sybyl Mol2 format.

MOLECULE_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in the old DEFAULT_TYPE format (InChI) to a molecule in the current DEFAULT_TYPE format (MDL Molfile). This function is useful when updating a database with a new version of Mychem.
MOLECULE_TO_SERIALIZEDOBMOL() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a serialized OBMol object. The SQL type of the serialized object is a binary string.
MOLFILE_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in MDL Molfile (V2000) format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_MOLFILE() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in MDL Molfile (V2000) format.
PDB_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in PDB format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
SMILES_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in SMILES format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_SMILES converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to molecule in SMILES format.

note.para: If you need a single canonical form for any particular molecule, regardless of atom order, the use of the function should be preferred.

listitem.para: MOLECULE_TO_CANONICAL_SMILES converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in Canonical SMILES format.
V3000_TO_MOLECULE() converts a molecule in MDL Molfile (V3000) format to a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format.
MOLECULE_TO_V3000() converts a molecule in DEFAULT_TYPE format to a molecule in MDL Molfile (V3000) format.

sect1.title: Helper Commands
sect1.para: This section details helper functions. They permit to get informations about the Mychem environment.

listitem.para: INCHI_VERSION() returns the version of the InChI library.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT INCHI_VERSION(); -> 1.02

listitem.para: MYCHEM_VERSION() returns the Mychem version.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT MYCHEM_VERSION(); -> 0.9.1

listitem.para: OPENBABEL_VERSION() returns the Open Babel version.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT OPENBABEL_VERSION(); -> 2.3.0

sect1.title: Modification Commands
sect1.para: This section describes modification functions that modify chemical structures. The following functions are fully working starting on version 0.6.0 of Mychem.

note.para: If a function of this section fails, it returns an empty string.

listitem.para: ADD_HYDROGENS() adds hydrogens to a molecule (makes explicit the hydrogen atoms).
REMOVE_HYDROGENS() removes the hydrogens from a molecule (makes implicit the hydrogen atoms).
STRIP_SALTS() removes all atoms except for the larger contiguous fragment.

sect1.title: Molmatch Commands
sect1.para: The molmatch functions permit to compare chemical structures.

listitem.para: BIT_FP_AND() operates on two fingerprints (bit patterns) of equal length and performs the logical AND operation on each pair of corresponding bits. In each pair, the result is 1 if the both bits are 1. Otherwise, the result is 0. If the two fingerprints do not have the same length, the function returns NULL.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT BIT_FP_AND(fingerprint1,fingerprint2); -> binary fingerprint

note.para: The function is very useful when working with structure fingerprints. For example, if a molecule (with a fingerprint fp1) is a substructure of an other molecule (with a fingerprint fp2), the following property is observed:

listitem.para: BIT_FP_COUNT() returns the number of bits that are set in the fingerprint binary representation.

BIT_FP_OR() operates on two fingerprints (bit patterns) of equal length and performs the logical OR operation on each pair of corresponding bits. In each pair, if the first bit is 1 or the second bit is 1 (or both), the result is 1. Otherwise, the result is 0. If the two fingerprints do not have same length, the function returns NULL.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT BIT_FP_OR(fingerprint1,fingerprint2); -> binary fingerprint

listitem.para: MATCH_SUBSTRUCT() checks if a query_smarts fragment is a substructure of a reference_obmol molecule. The first argument is a SMARTS string, whereas the second argument is a serialized OBMol object. The second argument type is generated by the function. If the query_smarts is a substructure of reference_obmol, the function returns 1, otherwise, it returns 0.

note.para: If the function encounter an error, it returns NULL.

listitem.para: SUBSTRUCT_ATOM_IDS() returns the atom ids of a reference_obmol molecule that are contained in substructures matching a query_smarts fragment. The first argument is a SMARTS string, whereas the second argument is a serialized OBMol object. The second argument type is generated by the function. If a reference_obmol molecule contains several fragments matching a query_smarts fragment, a list of items is returned. Each item contains a fragment's atom ids and is separated from the next item by a semicolon character.

note.para: If the function encounter an error, it returns NULL.

listitem.para: SUBSTRUCT_COUNT() returns the number of query_smarts fragments founded in a reference_obmol molecule. The first argument is a SMARTS string, whereas the second argument is a serialized OBMol object. The second argument type is generated by the function.

note.para: If the function encounter an error, it returns NULL.

listitem.para: TANIMOTO() returns the tanimoto coefficient between two fingerprints. Fingerprints are bit patterns and can be generated with the function. The return value is comprised between 0 and 1. The higher the tanimoto coefficient is, the more the molecules are similar.

sect1.title: Property Commands
sect1.para: This section describes several functions that calculate molecular properties.

listitem.para: EXACTMASS() returns the monoisotopic molecular weight of a molecule. The monoisotopic molecular weight is defined as the molecular weight calculated using the mass of the most abundant isotope for each element of a molecule. The unit of the return value is g.mol-1.
IS_2D() returns 1 if a molecule has 2D coordinates.
IS_3D() returns 1 if a molecule has 3D coordinates.
IS_CHIRAL() returns 1 if a molecule is chiral.
MOLFORMULA() returns the molecular formula of a molecule.
MOLLOGP() returns the LogP of a molecule.

note.para: Note that the result of this function is depending on the hydrogen atoms. If there is any doubt on the presence of hydrogen atoms in the molecule, it is recommended to use the function.

listitem.para: MOLMR() returns the molar refractivity of a molecule. The unit of the return value is J.mol-1.K-1.

note.para: Note that the result of this function is depending on the hydrogen atoms. If there is any doubt on the presence of hydrogen atoms in the molecule, it is recommended to use the function.

listitem.para: MOLPSA() returns the topological polar surface area of a molecule. The unit of the return value is Ã…2.

note.para: Note that the result of this function is depending on the hydrogen atoms. If there is any doubt on the presence of hydrogen atoms in the molecule, it is recommended to use the function.

listitem.para: MOLWEIGHT() returns the molecular weight of a molecule. The unit of the return value is g.mol-1.
NUMBER_OF_ACCEPTORS() returns the number of hydrogen-bond acceptors in a molecule.

note.para: Note that the result of this function is depending on the hydrogen atoms. If there is any doubt on the presence of hydrogen atoms in the molecule, it is recommended to use the function.

listitem.para: NUMBER_OF_ATOMS() returns the number of atoms in a molecule.
NUMBER_OF_BONDS() returns the number of bonds in a molecule.
NUMBER_OF_DONORS() returns the numbers of hydrogen-bond donors in a molecule.

note.para: Note that the result of this function is depending on the presence of hydrogen atoms in the molecule. If the hydrogen atoms are not described by the molecule, the function must be used. The two following examples described the effect of the ADD_HYDROGENS function:

listitem.para: NUMBER_OF_HEAVY_ATOMS() returns the number of heavy atoms in a molecule (all atoms except hydrogen).
NUMBER_OF_RINGS() returns the number of rings in a molecule.
NUMBER_OF_ROTABLE_BONDS() returns the number of rotable bonds in a molecule.
TOTAL_CHARGE() returns the total charge of a molecule.
listitem.screen: mysql> SELECT TOTAL_CHARGE(SMILES_TO_MOLECULE('NCC(=O)[O-]')); -> -1
